name: FTDI FT232R
description: Common USB-to-serial adapter frequently used as a JTAG debugger or serial console for embedded device access

name: FTDI FT2232
description: Dual-channel USB-to-serial/JTAG adapter used for hardware debugging, SPI/I2C sniffing, and firmware extraction

name: FTDI FT232H
description: High-speed USB-to-serial/JTAG/SPI/I2C adapter commonly used for hardware hacking and firmware analysis

name: FTDI FT4232H
description: Quad-channel USB-to-serial/JTAG adapter used for multi-target hardware debugging scenarios

name: Hak5 USB Rubber Ducky
description: Keystroke injection attack platform that emulates a keyboard to execute pre-programmed payloads

name: Hak5 Bash Bunny
description: Multi-function USB attack platform capable of keystroke injection, network attacks, and storage exfiltration

name: Hak5 Packet Squirrel
description: Inline network implant for packet capture, man-in-the-middle attacks, and DNS spoofing

name: CH340 USB-to-Serial
description: Low-cost USB-to-serial adapter commonly found on debug boards and used for embedded device console access

name: Silicon Labs CP210x
description: USB-to-UART bridge controller used in debug adapters and embedded development boards

name: Microchip PICkit
description: Microchip JTAG/SWD programmer and debugger for PIC and ARM microcontrollers

name: Arduino Uno
description: Arduino development board that can be reprogrammed as a USB HID attack device (BadUSB)

name: Arduino Leonardo
description: Arduino board with native USB HID capability, commonly used for BadUSB keystroke injection attacks

name: Teensy (HID)
description: Teensy microcontroller in HID mode, commonly used for USB keystroke injection attacks

name: Teensy (Serial)
description: Teensy microcontroller in serial mode, used for hardware debugging and USB attack development

name: Segger J-Link
description: Professional JTAG/SWD debug probe for ARM processors, used for firmware extraction and analysis

name: Segger J-Link Plus
description: High-end JTAG/SWD debug probe with enhanced trace capabilities for ARM debugging

name: ARM CMSIS-DAP
description: ARM debug access port interface used for SWD/JTAG debugging of ARM Cortex processors

name: TI Stellaris ICDI
description: Texas Instruments In-Circuit Debug Interface for Stellaris and Tiva microcontrollers

name: Hak5 LAN Turtle
description: Covert network implant disguised as a USB Ethernet adapter for persistent network access and man-in-the-middle attacks

name: Hak5 WiFi Pineapple
description: Rogue wireless access point platform for WiFi auditing, credential harvesting, and man-in-the-middle attacks

name: GreatFET One
description: Open-source hardware security research tool for USB protocol analysis, JTAG, and SPI flash dumping

name: Facedancer (GreatFET)
description: USB device emulator used for USB fuzzing, protocol analysis, and BadUSB research

name: NXP LPC-Link
description: NXP debug probe for LPC ARM microcontrollers, used for JTAG and SWD firmware access

name: STMicroelectronics ST-LINK/V2
description: STM32 JTAG/SWD debug probe for ARM Cortex microcontrollers, used for firmware extraction

name: STMicroelectronics ST-LINK/V2-1
description: Integrated STM32 debug probe found on Nucleo boards, used for SWD debugging and programming
